issues.title: UpdatePrimaryMassLedgerDiagnostics() never called (dead code)
observations: The most sensitive conservation diagnostic (ledger vs component sum, 0.1%/1.0% thresholds) is silent. All display fields it would populate (`primaryMassStatus`, `primaryMassAlarm`, `primaryMassDrift_lb`, etc.) remain at defaults. UI appears "OK" when it should not. Init.cs:184 has a comment referencing it as if it runs â€” actively misleading.
High â€” False confidence. The diagnostic's existence in the codebase implies the system is monitored. It is not. Solver-vs-ledger divergence is undetectable at runtime.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed â€” Method added in v5.3.0 Stage 6 (Logging.cs:470, 114 lines, fully implemented). Call site in `StepSimulation()` was never added. Full codebase grep confirms zero call sites.
issues.resolution_candidate: Resolved v0.1.0.0 â€” Call site added at end of `StepSimulation()` after `UpdateInventoryAudit(dt)`. Default status changed from `"OK"` to `"NOT_CHECKED"`. Init reset added for all diagnostic state fields. Diagnostic executes every physics timestep.
links: Blocked by: CS-0001, CS-0003. Blocks: CS-0007.
Blocked by: CS-0001, CS-0003. Blocks: CS-0007.
IP-0001 â€” Primary Mass Conservation â€” Phase C

issues.title: No UI display for primary ledger drift
observations: Even after CS-0006 resurrects the diagnostic, operator/developer has no visual indicator of ledger drift. The three existing mass checks (massError_lbm, VCT flow imbalance, inventory conservation) don't detect solver-vs-ledger divergence. Engine fields exist but are unused by UI.
Medium â€” Conservation errors at the primary level are invisible unless the developer reads log output. No at-a-glance indicator in the validation tab.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed â€” TabValidation.cs:158-242 has 12 PASS/FAIL checks; none reference `primaryMassDrift`. UI was not updated when the diagnostic method was added in v5.3.0.
issues.resolution_candidate: Resolved v0.1.0.0 â€” "Primary Ledger Drift" row added to TabValidation using `DrawCheckRowThreeState` (100 lb warn / 1000 lb error thresholds). Shows "Not checked yet" until first coupled step, then displays drift percentage.
links: Blocked by: CS-0006
Blocked by: CS-0006
IP-0001 â€” Primary Mass Conservation â€” Phase C

issues.title: No SG secondary pressure alarm
observations: SG secondary pressure is computed and displayed but has no alarm. Real SG safety valves lift at ~1085 psia. During isolated boiling, SG pressure can rise without annunciation.
Low â€” Primarily an operational realism gap. No conservation impact. Becomes more relevant for abnormal scenarios and cooldown operations.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed â€” AlarmManager built for primary-side alarms. SG secondary alarms were not in scope.
links: Related: CS-0009
IP-0007 â€” SG Energy and Pressure Validation

issues.title: Acceptance tests are formula-only, not simulation-validated
observations: All 10 acceptance tests pass by checking calculation correctness. Each contains "REQUIRES SIMULATION" note. `RunAllTests()` returns 10/10 PASSED without running any simulation. The quality gate is satisfied vacuously.

High â€” False confidence. Tests validate Rules R1-R8 mathematically but don't verify the rules are enforced at runtime (they aren't â€” CS-0001). Test suite suggests conservation architecture is validated when it is not.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed â€” Tests designed as architectural validation (correct formulas). Simulation validation deferred to manual observation. No end-to-end test harness exists.
links: Related: CS-0001 (tests validate rules that aren't enforced)
IP-0010 â€” Test Infrastructure

issues.title: No regime transition logging
observations: When alpha crosses regime boundaries (0 to blended to 1), no event is logged. Plant mode transitions are logged (Alarms.cs:85-89) but regime transitions are not. Debugging mass issues across regime boundaries requires inferring regime from RCP count.
Low â€” Pure observability gap. No conservation or physics impact. Regime transitions are deterministic from RCP state.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed â€” Regime is an internal physics concept, not an operator-visible alarm. Logging was not prioritized.
links: None
IP-0012 â€” Observability

issues.title: PZR 100% level, zero steam model may be clamping dynamics
observations: Extended periods with PZR at 100% level with no steam volume while heaters run. Can hide expansion/volume bookkeeping errors and affects realism of the bubble formation transition.
Medium â€” If PZR is water-solid at 100%, thermal expansion must go somewhere. Clamping at 100% without steam volume may absorb expansion errors silently.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed correct â€” PZR at 100% level with zero steam is physically correct for solid plant operations. The solid-regime pressurizer IS water-full by definition (per NRC HRTD 19.2). Thermal expansion of PZR water exits through the surge line, reflected in rising Surge Flow values (1.2â†’8.2 gpm across solid regime). The expansion is accommodated by CVCS PI-controlled letdown balance (v0.2.0.0 transport delay fix). No clamping error exists.
issues.resolution_candidate: Resolved v0.3.0.0 â€” Investigation confirms behavior is physically correct. Log evidence: Surge Flow rises monotonically (1.2â†’8.2 gpm) during solid ops, confirming thermal expansion exits through surge line. PZR level at 100% with zero steam is the correct initial condition for solid plant. No code change required.
links: Related: CS-0028 (bubble flag timing).
Heatup Master Issue Registry â€” ISSUE-LOG-003
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase â€” Phase B
tags: Primary Thermodynamics â€” PZR State Machine

issues.title: Bubble detection threshold aligns with saturation (validation item)
observations: Bubble detection occurs near Tsat crossing (positive), but robustness across modes and edge cases should be verified. This is primarily a validation/confidence item.
Low â€” Current behavior appears correct in nominal cases. Risk is in edge cases or mode transitions where threshold may not trigger reliably.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed correct â€” Bubble detection triggers at T_pzr = 435.43Â°F vs T_sat = 435.83Â°F (0.4Â°F subcooling margin) at 8.25 hr sim time. Detection occurs within 1Â°F of saturation, which is the correct threshold per SolidPlantPressure detection logic. The T_pzr â†’ T_sat crossing is clean and produces immediate DETECTION phase transition with no pressure discontinuity (P remains 365.1 psia through detection).
issues.resolution_candidate: Resolved v0.3.0.0 â€” Investigation confirms detection threshold is correct. Log evidence: T_pzr = 435.43Â°F at detection vs T_sat = 435.83Â°F (0.4Â°F margin). Pressure continuous through detection (365.1 psia before and after). No code change required.
links: Related: CS-0028.
Heatup Master Issue Registry â€” ISSUE-LOG-007
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase â€” Phase B

issues.title: Post-bubble pressure escalation magnitude questionable
observations: Rapid pressure rise after bubble onset despite strongly negative net CVCS at times. Pressure escalation magnitude appears inconsistent with the energy/mass inputs.

Medium-High â€” Suggests two-phase energy balance or compressible volume error. Pressure should respond to the balance of steam generation rate, condensation, and CVCS flows â€” not escalate against negative net flow.
hypotheses: Suspected â€” Two-phase pressure coupling in CoupledThermo or PressurizerPhysics may overweight steam generation or underweight mass removal. Alternatively, energy input to PZR may be incorrectly high.
links: Related: CS-0029, CS-0030.
Heatup Master Issue Registry â€” ISSUE-LOG-008
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase
tags: Primary Thermodynamics â€” Two-Phase Energy Balance

issues.title: Bubble phase labeling inconsistent with observed thermodynamics
observations: Phase reported as "DRAIN" while pressure and steam behavior indicate pressurization/boiling transition behavior. Misleading telemetry that can hide wrong control branch execution.

Medium â€” Incorrect phase label means the control logic may be executing the wrong branch. DRAIN phase should show decreasing PZR water level and controlled letdown; if pressure is rising, the system is actually in PRESSURIZE or transition.
hypotheses: Suspected â€” State machine transition conditions may not check pressure/steam behavior, only water level or timer-based triggers.
links: Related: CS-0028, CS-0024.
Heatup Master Issue Registry â€” ISSUE-LOG-009
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase
tags: Primary Thermodynamics â€” State Machine Logic

issues.title: Bubble flag/state timing inconsistent with saturation and pressure rise
observations: Conditions show Tsat behavior and rapid pressurization while "Bubble Formed = NO" persists for some intervals. Wrong state gating leads to wrong control logic path â€” the system may be executing solid-regime logic when it should be in two-phase.

High â€” State gating error means the wrong physics model branch runs. If bubble exists but flag says NO, the engine runs SolidPlantPressure instead of CoupledThermo/PressurizerPhysics, producing incorrect pressure and mass distribution.
hypotheses: Suspected â€” Bubble detection may have a latency or hysteresis that delays flag transition while thermodynamic conditions have already crossed saturation. Alternatively, detection may check wrong state variable.
links: Related: CS-0025, CS-0027, CS-0024.
Heatup Master Issue Registry â€” ISSUE-LOG-011
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase
tags: Primary Thermodynamics â€” State Machine Timing

issues.title: Very high pressure ramp while RCS heat rate near zero
observations: Pressure climbs strongly while RCS temperature barely moves in certain window. Pressure and temperature should be coupled through saturation properties â€” pressure rising without temperature change suggests energy accounting or compressibility defect.

Medium-High â€” Points to energy accounting, compressibility, or state coupling defect. In two-phase equilibrium, pressure and temperature are locked together through Tsat(P). Decoupled behavior indicates a model error.
hypotheses: Suspected â€” Pressure may be driven by PZR heater energy alone (steam compression) while RCS temperature response is suppressed by large thermal mass or SG heat removal. Alternatively, pressure model may have a decoupled pathway.
links: Related: CS-0026, CS-0030.
Heatup Master Issue Registry â€” ISSUE-LOG-012
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase
tags: Primary Thermodynamics â€” Two-Phase Energy Balance

issues.title: Nonlinear/inconsistent sensitivity of pressure to CVCS sign changes
observations: CVCS net flips sign, but pressure response doesn't scale plausibly. Adding mass should raise pressure (in two-phase: compresses steam bubble); removing mass should lower pressure. Response magnitude should be roughly proportional to mass change.

Medium â€” Mass-pressure coupling is still weak or overridden in two-phase regime. With canonical mass now active (v0.1.0.0), this coupling should be more explicit, but the symptom suggests the solver's pressure response to mass change is not scaled correctly.
hypotheses: Suspected â€” CoupledThermo pressure iteration may not weight mass change correctly in the convergence loop. The solver may be dominated by thermal effects and insensitive to mass-driven pressure changes.
links: Related: CS-0026, CS-0029.
Heatup Master Issue Registry â€” ISSUE-LOG-013
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase

issues.title: UI/Input unresponsive after Editor close (main thread starvation suspected)
observations: Simulation continues updating (physics loop runs) but selecting/navigating UI becomes unresponsive ("hang" perception). Onset is delayed â€” not immediate. Trigger correlates with closing Unity Editor during or after a run. No obvious memory growth. **Blocks overnight validation runs and operator usability.**

None directly â€” physics continues executing. However, inability to interact with the running simulation prevents validation, parameter adjustment, and controlled shutdown. Effectively blocks all long-run acceptance testing (Phase E of any domain plan).
links: Cross-cutting â€” affects all domain validation runs. Supersedes all non-runtime work in priority.
IP-0009 â€” Performance and Runtime Architecture

issues.title: CVCS thermal mixing contribution missing from RCS energy balance
observations: Charging water enters the RCS at VCT temperature (~100Â°F) but is modeled as mass-only with no thermal mixing. At 75 gpm charging with a Î”T of ~300Â°F (RCS at ~400Â°F vs charging at ~100Â°F), this represents approximately 0.15 MW of cooling that is currently ignored. The omission contributes to a slight overestimation of RCS heatup rate during CVCS operations.

Low â€” Not critical for heatup accuracy (0.15 MW vs ~1.0 MW total heat input), but contributes to the cumulative energy balance gap. Becomes more significant at higher RCS temperatures where the charging Î”T is larger. A complete energy balance should include CVCS enthalpy transport.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed â€” CVCS flows are modeled as mass-only boundary flows (lbm in/out) per the canonical mass conservation architecture (v0.1.0.0). Enthalpy transport was not in scope for mass conservation. Charging temperature is available (VCT model tracks temperature), but the thermal contribution is not computed or applied to the RCS energy equation.
links: Originated from: CS-0033 (Finding C). Related: CS-0034 (equilibrium ceiling â€” CVCS cooling would contribute to equilibrium).
CS-0033 Diagnostic Audit â€” Finding C
IP-0008 â€” CVCS Energy Balance and VCT Flow Accounting
tags: CVCS â€” Primary Energy Balance Boundary

issues.title: DRAIN phase duration excessive â€” PZR requires ~4 hours to reach 25% level
observations: DRAIN phase from bubble detection (~100% PZR level) to target level (25%) takes approximately 4 simulated hours. This distorts the startup schedule: in a real plant, PZR drain to normal operating level takes on the order of 30â€“60 minutes at typical letdown/drain rates. The excessive duration also blocks validation runtime practicality â€” 4-hour DRAIN consumes significant wall-clock time at any simulation acceleration, making Phase E validation runs impractical.

High â€” If the net drain rate is significantly lower than modeled gpm would predict, this indicates either: (1) hidden inflow cancellation (charging/makeup opposing letdown during DRAIN), (2) unit conversion error (gpm vs gph, or seconds vs hours in flow integration), (3) valve coefficient or cap limiting effective drain flow below intended rate, (4) geometric-vs-mass mismatch in PZR level computation causing level to stall. Any of these would represent a mass flow or state computation error.
links: Related: CS-0026 (post-bubble pressure escalation), CS-0027 (bubble phase labeling). Related: CS-0035 (CVCS thermal mixing â€” CVCS flows during DRAIN).
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase
tags: Bubble Formation â€” Phase Controller / CVCS Flow Balance

issues.title: Surge line flow direction and net inventory display enhancement
observations: Surge flow display currently shows magnitude only, without explicit direction indicator. During DRAIN and PRESSURIZE phases, ambiguity exists about whether flow is PZRâ†’RCS or RCSâ†’PZR. Net CVCS flow and derived PZR mass change rate are not displayed, making it difficult to diagnose mass balance during transient phases. Operators must infer flow direction from other parameters.
None â€” Pure observability enhancement. No physics equations, conservation logic, or state computation changes.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed â€” UI displays surge flow magnitude without sign convention or directional indicator. No derived net mass change display exists.
links: Subsumed by: CS-0077 (HeatupValidationVisual unified dashboard redesign). Related: CS-0012 (regime transition logging). Related: CS-0036 (DRAIN duration â€” flow direction clarity aids diagnosis). Related: CS-0027 (bubble phase labeling).
DP-0008 unified instrumentation redesign scope (CS-0077)
IP-0020 closed as FAILED on 2026-02-15; CS reclassified to INVESTIGATING pending replacement planning.

issues.title: VCT conservation error growth (~1,700 gal at 15.75 hr)
observations: Dashboard shows VCT CONS ERR ~1,600â€“1,700 gal (failing) at 15.75 hr simulation time. VCT internal flows may be correct, but the verifier depends on the RCS-side `rcsInventoryChange_gal` term. If primary-side accounting drifts or is overwritten, VCT verification fails even with correct VCT flows. Creates cascading validation failures that mask the true root cause.

High â€” VCT conservation error growth indicates a boundary accounting mismatch between RCS and VCT subsystems. Either (1) VCT flow integration accumulates error over time, (2) the RCS-side inventory change term used in VCT verification drifts due to V*rho intermediate estimates, or (3) seal flow accounting (3 gpm/pump to VCT) creates a systematic offset. The error is monotonically growing, suggesting a rate error rather than a one-time offset.
hypotheses: Suspected â€” Multiple hypotheses: (a) VCT verifier uses `rcsInventoryChange_gal` which is mass-derived volume â€” subject to thermal expansion artifacts (same class as CS-0041). (b) Seal return flow accounting may mismatch between RCS boundary and VCT boundary. (c) CVCS flow integration may have a timestep-dependent drift.
links: Related: CS-0035 (CVCS thermal mixing â€” enthalpy transport may affect VCT verification). Related: CS-0041 (inventory audit baseline type mismatch â€” may share root cause in mass-derived vs geometric volume comparison).
FUTURE_ENHANCEMENTS_ROADMAP.md â€” v5.4.0 Issue #5, Technical Debt
IP-0008 â€” CVCS Energy Balance and VCT Flow Accounting
tags: CVCS â€” VCT Flow Boundary Accounting

issues.title: RVLIS indicator stale during PZR drain
observations: `RCSWaterMass` is not updated during drain operations, causing the RVLIS (Reactor Vessel Level Indication System) indicator to read stale mass values (~88%). This creates a false indication of stable inventory when liquid is actively being displaced from the PZR into the RCS or removed via letdown. Operators see RVLIS holding steady while PZR level drops, which is misleading.

High â€” RVLIS is a safety-grade level indicator in actual plants. Stale readings during drain represent a fidelity gap in operator-facing instrumentation. The stale value also affects any downstream computation that reads `RCSWaterMass` during the DRAIN phase, potentially including conservation diagnostics.
hypotheses: Suspected â€” During DRAIN phase, liquid mass moves from PZR (via steam displacement) and potentially via CVCS letdown. The `RCSWaterMass` field used for RVLIS may not be recomputed from the canonical mass ledger during the DRAIN phase, or the canonical ledger update may not propagate to RVLIS in the correct order.
links: Related: CS-0036 (DRAIN phase duration excessive â€” same phase, different symptom). Related: CS-0026 through CS-0030 (bubble formation and two-phase domain).
FUTURE_ENHANCEMENTS_ROADMAP.md â€” v5.4.0 Issue #3, Technical Debt
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase

issues.title: Inventory audit baseline type mismatch (geometric vs mass-derived gallons)
observations: Dashboard "SYSTEM TOTAL" and "INV ERROR" displays compare `initialSystemInventory_gal` (geometric volume at t=0) against `totalSystemInventory_gal` (mass-derived volume at runtime). As water heats from 100Â°F to 550Â°F, density decreases ~15%, producing a phantom "inventory error" of ~13,000+ gallons that is purely thermal expansion â€” not an actual conservation failure. This is a display metric defect, not a physics defect.

Medium â€” The mass conservation architecture (canonical ledger, `TotalPrimaryMass_lb`) is unaffected. However, the misleading display undermines operator confidence in conservation and produces false FAIL indications in the validation tab. The metric compares thermodynamically incompatible quantities (geometric baseline vs mass-derived runtime).
issues.root_cause: Confirmed â€” `initialSystemInventory_gal` is set at t=0 from `PlantConstants.RCS_WATER_VOLUME` (geometric, temperature-independent). `totalSystemInventory_gal` is computed at runtime from `RCSWaterMass / Ï(T,P)` (mass-derived, temperature-dependent). The difference grows with temperature as density decreases. At 400Â°F: phantom error â‰ˆ 13,474 gallons.
links: Related: CS-0007 (primary ledger drift UI â€” same observability domain). Related: CS-0039 (VCT conservation error â€” may share root cause in mass-derived vs geometric volume comparison).
FUTURE_ENHANCEMENTS_ROADMAP.md â€” v5.4.1 Part B, Technical Debt
IP-0011 â€” Validation and Diagnostic Display
tags: Validation / Diagnostic Display â€” Conservation Metric Integrity

issues.title: Pressurizer pressure boundary failure during bubble formation â€” runaway depressurization spiral
observations: Pressure collapses from ~368 psia to ~154 psia over ~2 hours during DRAIN phase despite 1.8 MW heaters at full power. Rate of depressurization accelerates: -78 psi/hr at DETECTION, -383 psi/hr during DRAIN. In a real PWR, heaters maintain saturation pressure during bubble formation; pressure should be stable or rising. The DRAIN phase cannot complete correctly under these conditions.

Critical â€” Dual energy application violates first law of thermodynamics. Heater power is consumed twice: (1) as sensible heat temperature rise in `IsolatedHeatingStep` (capped and discarded by T_sat clamp), and (2) as latent heat steam generation in `UpdateDrainPhase` via h_fg. The T_sat cap creates a ratchet effect where P_new = Psat(T_pzr) â‰¤ Psat(T_sat(P_old)) â‰¤ P_old, guaranteeing monotonic pressure decline every timestep.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed â€” Runaway depressurization feedback loop with four interacting mechanisms: (A) `IsolatedHeatingStep` applies heater energy as subcooled sensible heat dT = Q/(mCp), then caps T_pzr at T_sat(P_old); (B) Two-phase pressure override sets P_new = Psat(T_pzr) where T_pzr â‰¤ T_sat(P_old), so P_new â‰¤ P_old; (C) Next timestep: T_sat(P_new) < T_sat(P_old), cap ratchets lower; (D) `UpdateDrainPhase` independently generates steam from the same heater power via h_fg â€” double-counting the energy. Fundamental error: in two-phase conditions, heater energy should go entirely to latent heat (phase change at constant temperature/pressure), not sensible heat (temperature rise). The `IsolatedHeatingStep` subcooled liquid model is incorrect for two-phase PZR operation.
issues.resolution_candidate: Stage E FAILED â€” Pressure boundary collapse confirmed in interval logs at 8.00â€“10.00 hr sim time
links: CS-0036 (DRAIN duration excessive â€” likely same root cause), CS-0026 (post-bubble pressure escalation), CS-0034 (no equilibrium ceiling Regime 0/1 â€” related energy model), CS-0029 (high pressure ramp zero heat rate â€” related pressure model)
IP-0003 â€” Bubble Formation and Two-Phase
tags: Core Physics â€” Two-Phase Pressurizer Energy Partition

issues.title: Async log writer â€” move synchronous file I/O to background thread
observations: Synchronous `StreamWriter.Write` calls on the main thread can stall for milliseconds during disk flush, antivirus scan, or dense logging periods (e.g., DRAIN phase forensic logging). This manifests as intermittent frame time spikes rather than sustained unresponsiveness.
None â€” logging only, no physics changes.
links: CS-0032 (resolved â€” parent performance issue), CS-0045 (snapshot boundary), CS-0046 (parallelization)
IP-0009 â€” Performance and Runtime Architecture (Phase B â€” Deferred)

issues.title: Physics snapshot boundary â€” decouple physics compute from UI rendering
observations: Currently, physics writes to fields that UI reads on the same frame. This creates implicit coupling where UI must run after physics, and any field access is a potential race condition if physics is later moved off-thread.
None â€” snapshot values are identical to direct reads. Behavioral change: zero.
links: CS-0032 (resolved â€” parent performance issue), CS-0044 (async log writer â€” prerequisite), CS-0046 (parallelization â€” depends on this)
IP-0009 â€” Performance and Runtime Architecture (Phase C â€” Deferred)

issues.title: Physics parallelization â€” move simulation step to worker thread or Unity Jobs
observations: With physics on the main thread, simulation compute competes with UI rendering for frame budget. Moving physics off-thread would free main thread for input/rendering and enable higher simulation speeds.
Must be bit-identical to single-threaded results. Requires Phase C snapshot boundary (CS-0045) as prerequisite.
links: CS-0032 (resolved â€” parent performance issue), CS-0044 (async log writer â€” prerequisite), CS-0045 (snapshot boundary â€” prerequisite)

issues.title: Pressurizer does not recover pressure in two-phase condition under heater pressurize mode
observations: In two-phase operation, pressurizer temperature remains at saturation and pressure fails to increase despite heater pressurize operation; pressure may continue decreasing instead of stabilizing or rising.
links: DP-0002 - Pressurizer & Two-Phase Physics

issues.title: SG startup draining contract at ~200F is not wired into runtime execution path
observations: Technical documentation specifies SG draining at approximately 200F, but runtime scanning found only the StartDraining declaration and no invocation path.
Expected startup mass-state transition for SG secondary inventory appears unexecuted, risking mismatch between documented and simulated SG initial conditions.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0011 - Steam Generator Secondary Physics (Audit Reopen)

issues.title: HZP subsystem initialization occurs in UPDATE path (lazy init phase leakage)
observations: UpdateHZPSystems performs first-time setup in UPDATE via hzpSystemsInitialized guard.
GOLD lifecycle contract marks update-time initialization as a FAIL unless explicitly justified as exception.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0010 - Project Governance

issues.title: BubbleFormation initializes CVCS controller during UPDATE phase transition
observations: DRAIN->STABILIZE transition performs CVCSController.Initialize inside update-time state machine execution.
This mixes one-time setup with timestep evolution and violates lifecycle separation contract.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0002 - Pressurizer & Two-Phase Physics

issues.title: PlantConstants partials execute runtime calculation logic (GOLD constants-file fail gate)
observations: Constants files include executable runtime methods (unit conversion, flow/orifice calculations, branching letdown path logic).
GOLD file hygiene explicitly forbids runtime logic in constants files and treats this as a mandatory FAIL gate.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0010 - Project Governance

issues.title: Stage E primary-heat telemetry is aliased to SG removal, collapsing over-primary validation signal
observations: stageE_PrimaryHeatInput_MW is assigned from sgHeatTransfer_MW, then over-primary checks compare SG removal against this aliased value.
This creates gross/net semantic ambiguity and weakens integrity of Stage E energy mismatch diagnostics.

issues.title: Simulation-facing files exceed GOLD hard size limits without documented waiver
observations: Multiple simulation-facing files exceed the >1400 hard-fail threshold, increasing audit and ownership risk.
No waiver evidence found in reviewed governance artifacts for these files.

issues.title: Heatup engine state is exposed as ad-hoc mutable public fields without typed snapshot boundary
observations: HeatupSimEngine publishes broad mutable public state surface; UI bridge reads fields directly rather than consuming a structured snapshot contract.
This increases hidden coupling and state ownership ambiguity across engine/UI boundaries.

issues.title: PERF THREAD_BLOCKING_RISK: synchronous interval file writes execute on main simulation thread
observations: SaveIntervalLog is invoked from the simulation loop and uses File.WriteAllText synchronously.
At accelerated stepping, blocking I/O can consume frame budget and amplify jitter risk on Unity main thread.

Related: CS-0044

issues.title: PERF ALLOCATION_HOT_PATH: SG multi-node update allocates transient mixing array each step
observations: SGMultiNodeThermal.Update allocates new float[N] for mixingHeat on every call.
Recurring hot-path allocations raise GC pressure and frame-time variance as simulation duration/scenario count scales.

issues.title: PERF GC_PRESSURE_RISK: Stage E dynamic window analysis allocates via Queue.ToArray in recurring path
observations: Dynamic interval evaluation converts queue to array whenever 3-sample window is evaluated.
Though bounded, repeated conversion adds avoidable transient allocations during active diagnostic windows.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0009 - Performance & Runtime

issues.title: PERF LOGGING_SPAM: high-frequency Debug.Log calls embedded in simulation substep paths
observations: Startup and phase heat-balance diagnostics emit Debug.Log from code paths executed inside substep loop.
String formatting and console I/O in these paths can amplify frame jitter and editor/runtime overhead during accelerated runs.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0009 - Performance & Runtime

issues.title: CondensingHTC uses unsourced coefficient and hard clamps in physics correlation
observations: CondensingHTC applies C=50 and clamps HTC to [50,500] without provenance in the file header or inline source attribution.
Unsourced empirical constants in active physics equations violate GOLD C03 and can mask true thermodynamic response.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0002 - Pressurizer & Two-Phase Physics

issues.title: HeatupSimEngine header lacks mandatory GOLD C01 sections (SOURCES and UNITS)
observations: The core engine header includes PURPOSE/ARCH/GOLD but does not include explicit SOURCES and UNITS sections required by C01.
This is a mandatory GOLD conformance gate failure for header completeness.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0010 - Project Governance

issues.title: Validation failure: Bubble draw duration exceeds documented expectation (~165-180 min observed vs 30-60 min expected)
observations: Expected behavior: documentation and internal constants indicate bubble draw is a short operation (nominal ~40 min, practical ~30-60 min) while level drops toward ~25% with startup-band pressure control.
Observed behavior: in `IP-0019_Extended_20260215_081706`, DRAIN runs from 8.50 hr (90.6%) to 11.25 hr (25.5%), i.e., ~165 min; transition to COMPLETE appears at ~11.50 hr.

Acceptance criteria: (1) DRAIN start->complete <=60 min (pass), <=40 min (advisory), (2) pressure remains in startup band while level drops toward ~25%, (3) closure blocked until these gates are validated in runtime logs.
hypotheses: Duration overrun is multi-factor: state-machine transition logic is level-only, CVCS schedule imposes a fixed post-CCP baseline, and volumetric displacement semantics are not strongly enforced in DRAIN.
issues.resolution_candidate: Pending preliminary investigation package under approved plans DP-0002 and DP-0004. No code changes authorized in this phase.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0002 - Pressurizer & Two-Phase Physics

issues.title: DRAIN progression is strongly constrained by fixed post-CCP net outflow policy (75 letdown, 44 charging, net 31 gpm)
observations: Expected behavior: if steam displacement is primary, DRAIN progression should not be explained mainly by fixed CVCS net outflow after CCP start.

Observed behavior: documentation indicates multi-orifice letdown capability (2x75 + 1x45 gpm, capped to 120 gpm), but active DRAIN uses fixed 75/0->44 policy (net 31 gpm after CCP start). Measured post-CCP implied drain (~9.00->11.25 hr) is ~49.0 gpm, indicating CVCS baseline plus additional displacement contribution.

Acceptance criteria: runtime evidence must show DRAIN progression is not solely dominated by CVCS net outflow when displacement is intended primary; multi-orifice authority and its impact on drain progression must be explicitly validated or formally waived.
hypotheses: The fixed post-CCP net outflow acts as the dominant baseline limiter, with displacement adding variable margin rather than governing progression directly.
DRAIN currently behaves like a single-drain-policy regime even though the codebase contains multi-orifice infrastructure for non-DRAIN operation.
issues.resolution_candidate: Pending procedure-alignment and coupling-policy investigation under approved plan DP-0004; multi-orifice finding folded into this issue.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0004 - CVCS / Inventory Control
Related: CS-0072 and CS-0076

issues.title: Steam displacement declared primary, but DRAIN volumetric reconciliation path de-emphasizes steam mass-to-volume closure
observations: Expected behavior: if steam displacement is primary, steam generation and volumetric closure should directly govern level reduction under total-volume constraint.

Observed behavior: DRAIN computes water volume from water mass with floor to target water volume; steam volume is residual, while explicit steam mass <- V*rho reconciliation is intentionally disabled in this path.
Acceptance criteria: volumetric displacement path must be explicitly validated as a primary contributor to level reduction and remain mass-conservative.
hypotheses: Current mass-first derivation is conservative for inventory accounting but may under-express volumetric displacement intent, making CVCS schedule appear overly dominant.
issues.resolution_candidate: Pending targeted volumetric-closure design under approved plan DP-0002.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0002 - Pressurizer & Two-Phase Physics
Related: CS-0072 and CS-0075

issues.title: 40-minute DRAIN constant is advisory only; state machine transition is level-threshold driven
observations: Expected behavior: internal nominal DRAIN duration constant (~40 min) should influence transition validation when duration materially exceeds expectation.
Observed behavior: `BUBBLE_PHASE_DRAIN_HR` is not consumed by transition logic; DRAIN exits when `pzrLevel <= target + 0.5`, with pressure-rate advisory only.
Acceptance criteria: DRAIN transition validation must enforce <=60 min pass and <=40 min advisory, in addition to existing level and pressure checks.
hypotheses: Because duration is not a gate, prolonged drain can pass phase progression as long as level threshold is eventually met.
issues.resolution_candidate: Pending state-machine validation gate design in approved plan DP-0002.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0002 - Pressurizer & Two-Phase Physics
Related: CS-0072

issues.title: Procedure alignment risk: startup reference max-letdown/min-charging intent differs from fixed DRAIN policy (75/0->44)
observations: Expected behavior: startup procedure references maximizing letdown and minimizing charging while drawing the bubble, with pressure held in startup band; source documents also describe multi-orifice letdown capability and a 120 gpm upper limit during heatup operations.
Observed behavior: implementation uses fixed DRAIN policy (75 gpm letdown, charging 0 then 44 gpm after CCP start at 80% level) and does not apply dynamic orifice lineup logic in active DRAIN.

Acceptance criteria: either (a) implement a documented procedure-aligned flow schedule that explicitly uses/justifies available orifice authority, or (b) formally justify fixed policy with validation proving duration and pressure-band gates.
hypotheses: Procedure-to-implementation divergence narrows control authority during draw and contributes to prolonged duration risk.
A deliberate simplification to fixed DRAIN policy may have overridden documented multi-orifice operating flexibility without a formal validation waiver.
issues.resolution_candidate: Pending procedure alignment decision under approved plan DP-0004.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0004 - CVCS / Inventory Control
Related: CS-0073 and CS-0072

issues.title: HeatupValidationVisual redesign from tabbed layout to unified instrumentation screen
observations: Problem statement: the current HeatupValidationVisual tab architecture fragments critical telemetry across multiple views and forces operators to hunt for state during validation runs.
Redesign objective: replace tabbed telemetry navigation with a single unified, high-density instrumentation screen based on Dashboard Proposal.png.
Layout requirement: all key telemetry must be visible simultaneously at 1920x1080 with no scrolling.
Alarm hierarchy requirement: top alarm strip is highest visual priority and displays active alarms with compact trend indicators, limited to 4-6 active alarms.

Section grouping requirement: distinct, always-visible groupings for Primary (RCS pressure/temperature/trends), Pressurizer (pressure/level/temperature/subcooling/heaters/sprays), Secondary (SG pressure/temperature with worst-case indicators), Inventory/CVCS (charging/letdown/net flow/system mass/VCT level), and System Mass/Conservation with drift indicator.
Trend requirement: each major section provides uniform micro-trend sparklines with 3-minute lookback; full graph panels are excluded from this scope.
Flow awareness requirement: net flow direction and rate must be continuously emphasized both numerically and visually.
Performance requirement: UI update loop must be rate-limited to <=10 Hz using fixed-size ring buffers for trend samples.
Runtime safety requirement: no per-frame allocations and no LINQ in update loops; redesign must not measurably increase frame time at 10x simulation speed.
Availability requirement: UI must degrade gracefully when telemetry is unavailable (stale/missing data surfaced without exception spam or hard UI failure).
Acceptance gate: closure requires visual verification against the design reference and an under-load runtime check at 10x simulation speed confirming performance constraints.

evidence.notes: authoritative visual/layout reference for unified screen

issues.root_cause: The tabbed monitoring design increases cognitive load and delays anomaly recognition because subsystem state must be mentally reassembled across separate views.
issues.resolution_candidate: FAILED under IP-0020 closeout; unified dashboard redesign did not meet acceptance for closure.
links: Scope boundary: UI redesign only for HeatupValidationVisual presentation layer; no physics model changes, no validation logic changes, and no acceptance logic changes.
Data boundary: dashboard must consume a read-only telemetry snapshot interface and must not read simulation/physics internals directly.
Out of scope: reactor/pressurizer/CVCS physics behavior, validation scenario sequencing, acceptance-rule thresholds, and non-dashboard workflow refactors.
IP-0020 closed as FAILED on 2026-02-15; CS-0077 is closed as FAILED by governance direction.

issues.title: SG secondary pressure response does not begin at RCP circulation onset; rise is delayed until near-boiling
observations: Technical documentation defines SG warmup as simultaneous heating and pressurization: as RCP heat input warms SG secondary, pressure should rise with temperature and later be regulated by steam dump control.

Current build logs show SG secondary pressure remains near blanket floor (~17 psia) from first non-zero RCP circulation through extended post-bubble RCP-driven warmup and temperature rise, then increases only near/after boiling onset, indicating delayed pressure response inconsistent with documented warmup behavior.

Scope note: this CS starts at first non-zero RCP circulation (ramp onset) after bubble precondition and does not require full pump ramp completion. Bubble formation/draining timing defects are tracked separately under existing bubble-phase CS items and are not duplicated here.

In latest build run, with RCPs at 4/4 and SG top node increasing from 109.53F to 216.90F (13.25hr -> 16.00hr), SG pressure remains only 17.1 -> 17.8 psia; pressure rise accelerates only near 234.95F/255.31F around boiling transition.

Acceptance criteria: SG secondary pressure response must begin at circulation onset (first non-zero RCP state) and continue directionally upward through warmup, even if initial increments are small, without remaining floor-clamped until near-boiling transition.
hypotheses: Startup pressure source selection and/or floor-clamped boundary behavior in OPEN_PREHEAT and early ISOLATED_HEATUP is suppressing expected compressibility/thermal-expansion pressure rise.
Pressure evolution may be over-coupled to boiling activation thresholds, producing near-flat pre-boil pressure instead of gradual warmup pressurization.
issues.resolution_candidate: Pending implementation of pre-boil pressurization coupling consistent with documented SG warmup process under DP-0011.
links: Assigned DP: DP-0011 - Steam Generator Secondary Physics (Audit Reopen)
Related closed chain: CS-0017, CS-0019, CS-0020, CS-0054 (reopened symptom class under current build evidence).
Prerequisite dependency (separate scope): bubble formation/draining issue chain CS-0072, CS-0074, CS-0075, CS-0076.

issues.title: RCP startup permissive is configured below documented minimum startup pressure requirements.
observations: Derived from Conformance Audit finding F-001.
RCP startup permissive is configured below documented minimum startup pressure requirements.
Requirement expectation: NRC HRTD Section 3.2 requires no RCP start below 400 psig.
Current implementation mismatch: PlantConstants.Pressure sets MIN_RCP_PRESSURE_PSIG = 320f and CanStartRCP uses that threshold.
Recommended action from audit: Fix.

evidence.notes: F-001 reference expectation: NRC HRTD Section 3.2 requires no RCP start below 400 psig.
F-001 implementation evidence: PlantConstants.Pressure sets MIN_RCP_PRESSURE_PSIG = 320f and CanStartRCP uses that threshold.

issues.title: PZR bubble closure path shows persistent non-convergence with large residuals and post-residual renormalization masking.
observations: Derived from PZR bubble behavior investigation dated 2026-02-15.
Bubble closure diagnostics show widespread non-convergence during STABILIZE and PRESSURIZE phases, with residuals remaining in the thousands of ft^3.
Evidence indicates residual handling is followed by volume renormalization to total PZR volume, which can mask unresolved closure error and produce discontinuous level/pressure behavior.
Pressure-unit consistency checks in this path were nominal; primary concern is closure convergence and state acceptance criteria.

evidence.notes: Diagnosis shortlist ranks closure non-convergence as most likely; reports failed shadow convergence counts (baseline 269/269 failed) and residuals up to about 5000 ft^3.
Contains STEP/SHADOW_STATUS entries showing MAX_ITER_REACHED and large residual values in BUBBLE_STABILIZE_MASS_CLOSURE and BUBBLE_PRESSURIZE_MASS_CLOSURE.
Report-cited post-residual volume renormalization location implicated in masking closure error.
Investigation completion disposition for DP-0012; transition recommendation READY_FOR_FIX.

hypotheses: Pressure-step cap is too restrictive relative to residual scale in bubble closure iterations.
State is accepted despite unresolved residual due to renormalization path.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed: bubble closure path can carry unresolved residual states under non-converged conditions, with renormalization behavior masking closure error.
issues.resolution_candidate: Recommended action: implement bounded iterative closure acceptance on residual tolerance, gate/remove renormalization on failed closure, and smooth/align stabilize vs pressurize level-floor transitions.
links: Investigation source: Updates/Investigations/PZR_Bubble_Behaviour_Investigation_2026-02-15.md
Run stamp: HeatupLogs/PZR_INVEST_20260215_173006
Tracking model: Validation child under CS-0093 umbrella remodel.
Closure gating: Keep CS-0091 active until CS-0093 evidence demonstrates convergence and continuity acceptance criteria are met.
Parent umbrella issue: CS-0093
Investigation disposition: Governance/Issues/DP-0012_Investigation_Completion_2026-02-16_115523.md

issues.title: Drain-phase CVCS letdown uses aggregate command-first logic that can force immediate 1-to-3 orifice opening.
observations: Derived from PZR orifice aggregation diagnosis dated 2026-02-15.

Investigation conclusion is CONFIRMED: in DRAIN, letdown is commanded as an aggregate 75..120 gpm signal, and orifice lineup is then inferred from that aggregate rather than computed from per-orifice hydraulic state.
At DRAIN entry, observed lineup jump from 1 open to 3 open with letdown shift around 79.7 to 120.0 gpm at the level-cliff onset.
This behavior is specific to DRAIN policy path and not a general non-DRAIN unconditional sum-of-all-orifices defect.

evidence.notes: Conclusion section confirms 3-as-1 aggregate-command behavior in DRAIN and documents exact mechanism/call chain.
First DRAIN diagnostic sample shows open_orifice_count=3 and letdown_total_gpm=120.000 at sim_hr=8.2664 with immediate level drop.
Report-cited aggregate DRAIN command assignment (letdown_gpm Lerp 75..120).
Report-cited DRAIN lineup forcing branch that maps aggregate letdown to 3-orifice open state.

hypotheses: Command-first DRAIN policy introduces discontinuous open-count transitions at phase entry.
Aggregate command path can decouple commanded letdown from instantaneous per-orifice hydraulic contributions.
issues.resolution_candidate: Recommended action: evaluate deriving DRAIN letdown from explicit per-orifice state/hydraulics or enforce transition continuity constraints with instrumentation-backed acceptance criteria.
links: Investigation source: Updates/Investigations/PZR_Orifice_Aggregation_Diagnosis_2026-02-15.md
Run stamp: HeatupLogs/PZR_INVEST_20260215_174056
Tracking model: Validation child under CS-0093 umbrella remodel.
Closure gating: Keep CS-0092 active until CS-0093 evidence demonstrates CVCS/orifice causality acceptance criteria are met.
Parent umbrella issue: CS-0093

issues.title: Complete Pressurizer (PZR) System Remodel to Align with Technical_Documentation and Replace Current Heuristic Bubble Model
observations: Structural refactor request: replace legacy hybrid PZR bubble model (pressure/volume residual iteration + heuristic phase logic + post-failure renormalization) with a thermodynamically grounded subsystem.
Current implementation concerns include persistent two-phase closure non-convergence, large residuals, missing persistent energy/enthalpy state, and nonphysical level/pressure discontinuities.
Requested remodel scope includes persistent thermodynamic state, mass-volume-energy closure, convergence-gated state commit, and removal of post-failure renormalization masking.
Requested remodel also includes physically continuous phase transitions, compressibility-consistent pressure response, and ledger-consistent causal CVCS interaction.
Cross-reference alignment is required against Technical_Documentation constants/limits/behavioral assumptions with explicit documentation of intentional deviations.

evidence.notes: Investigation documents persistent two-phase closure non-convergence, high residual magnitudes, and structural limitations of pressure-only closure behavior.
Diagnostic confirms DRAIN letdown/orifice aggregation mismatch and supports subsystem-level remodel scope for causal CVCS interaction.
Authoritative source set for remodel conformance; constants and behavioral assumptions must be traceable.
Investigation completion disposition for DP-0012; transition recommendation READY_FOR_FIX.

hypotheses: Incremental patching of the existing heuristic closure path is unlikely to deliver robust convergence and continuity targets across all bubble phases.
A control-volume energy-state formulation with coupled mass-volume-energy closure is required to remove structural discontinuities.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed: legacy heuristic PZR closure/control architecture lacks robust converged mass-volume-energy authority and consistent documentation-aligned behavior.
issues.resolution_candidate: Recommended action: execute full PZR subsystem remodel with acceptance targets: >95% solver convergence in bubble phases, bounded residuals for volume and energy, no post-failure renormalization masking, continuous phase transitions, and documented Technical_Documentation traceability for constants/behavior.
links: Directive source: User-issued CS logging instruction (2026-02-15)
Parent umbrella issue for related active issues: CS-0091, CS-0092
Tracking decision (accepted 2026-02-15): CS-0091 and CS-0092 remain active as validation children until CS-0093 acceptance evidence is complete.
Investigation disposition: Governance/Issues/DP-0012_Investigation_Completion_2026-02-16_115523.md

issues.title: Add Cold-Start Stabilization Hold and PZR Heater Off/Auto/Manual Control to Prevent Immediate Pressurization and Improve Operator Realism
observations: Startup currently allows immediate heater/pressurization engagement before post-init state settling, which can amplify nonphysical early transients and complicate diagnostics.

Requested mitigation includes Option A baseline: deterministic startup stabilization hold (10-20 s) with heaters OFF and pressurization actions inhibited until release, with explicit hold-active/released logging.

Requested operator-realism extension includes Option B: PZR heater mode switch (OFF / AUTO / MANUAL-disabled lockout) with startup default mode traceable to Cold Shutdown profile and visible in UI/telemetry.
Severity is logged as MEDIUM and should be upgraded to HIGH if evidence confirms this startup behavior materially contributes to bubble-phase solver instability.

evidence.notes: Motivation reference: startup transients and bubble-phase instability concerns are linked to immediate engagement behavior and diagnostic complexity.
Cold-start baseline audit identifies immediate full-power heater startup and implicit startup gating concerns that support stabilization-hold/control-gating investigation.
Investigation completion disposition for DP-0012; transition recommendation READY_FOR_FIX.

hypotheses: Immediate frame-1 heater/pressurization engagement injects artificial startup transient energy before control-volume states settle, increasing likelihood of downstream nonphysical behavior.
Explicit startup hold and/or operator-gated heater mode will reduce artificial early cliffs and improve repeatability and diagnostic attribution.
issues.root_cause: Confirmed: startup sequence permits early heater authority without fully explicit startup governance gating, producing potential nonphysical transient behavior.
issues.resolution_candidate: Recommended action: implement Option A as baseline (deterministic startup hold with inhibited heater/pressurization actions and explicit logs), then optionally add Option B heater OFF/AUTO/MANUAL-disabled control with UI/telemetry visibility; run startup-transient regression and escalate severity to HIGH if solver-instability linkage is confirmed.
links: Directive source: User-issued CS logging instruction (2026-02-15)
Related investigation: Updates/Investigations/PZR_Bubble_Behaviour_Investigation_2026-02-15.md
Related investigation: Updates/Investigations/Cold_Shutdown_Baseline_Deviation_Audit_2026-02-15.md
Investigation disposition: Governance/Issues/DP-0012_Investigation_Completion_2026-02-16_115523.md

issues.title: Modular architecture migration: coordinator + modular system extraction pipeline (PZR-first)
observations: Simulator stepping and state ownership are tightly coupled in monolithic flow, increasing regression risk and slowing validation, UI evolution, and manual controls work.

Migration approach is strangler-fig incremental: introduce coordinator and module contract, wrap current simulator as legacy module, then extract systems one-by-one while keeping simulator runnable after each checkpoint.

Required scope: PlantSimulationCoordinator lifecycle and timestep sequencing only (no physics), IPlantModule contract (Initialize, Step, Shutdown), LegacySimulatorModule adapter, PlantState authoritative shared state, StepSnapshot publishing each step for validation/UI, and PlantBus or TransferLedger for explicit transfer events.

Required scope: per-module feature flags (for example UseModularPZR) with safe legacy bypass, extraction order PZR -> CVCS -> RHR -> RCP -> Reactor -> RCS, and optional comparator or shadow mode for tolerance-based legacy-vs-modular comparisons with single-output application.
Out of scope: do not change PZR remodel physics in this CS except packaging behind module boundary during PZR extraction.

Done criteria must include coordinator-driven baseline equivalence with LegacySimulatorModule, stable StepSnapshot (time, dt, PlantState, TransferLedger, telemetry hooks) consumption by validation without module internals, documented repeatable extraction pattern, and explicit support for PZR-first pilot extraction under feature flag.

evidence.notes: Simulation step entry point discovered at StepSimulation(float dt); this is the legacy behavior seam for LegacySimulatorModule wrapping.
Current per-timestep sequencing path RunPhysicsStep(dt) invokes StepSimulation(dt) then PublishTelemetrySnapshot().
PublishTelemetrySnapshot() is the current snapshot publication point to replace or align with StepSnapshot.
Validation/UI hook currently pulls engine snapshot each Update via GetTelemetrySnapshot(); StepSnapshot must support this boundary without internal state reach-in.
Relevant prior PZR-focused plan for sequencing/context linkage.

hypotheses: Coordinator-owned sequencing plus module boundaries will reduce regression blast radius and allow parallel system evolution with explicit validation gates.
issues.resolution_candidate: Implement modular migration scaffold with coordinator, module contract, legacy adapter, authoritative PlantState plus StepSnapshot (time, dt, PlantState, TransferLedger, telemetry hooks), feature-flagged extraction pipeline (PZR first), comparator mode, and closure evidence package (build/compile confirmation, coordinator-path baseline run log, and module/snapshot contract notes).
links: Related issue: CS-0064 (typed snapshot boundary for validation).
Related issue: CS-0093 (PZR-first extraction boundary alignment; no physics remodel changes in this CS).
Related plan: Governance/ImplementationPlans/Closed/IP-0024 - Unified PZR Implementation Plan (Authority-First).md
Assigned domain plan: Governance/DomainPlans/DP-0010 - Project Governance.md

issues.title: PZR heaters capped after reaching operating pressure hold band
observations: During heatup runs, once the pressurizer enters operating pressure hold regime (HOLD_SOLID with solid pressure in band), heater output no longer ramps toward full power and remains materially below capacity.
Observed windows at 1.50 hr, 1.75 hr, and 2.00 hr show heater power constrained to approximately 0.35-0.69 MW while spray is disabled due to no running RCPs.
This behavior suggests active authority limiting by one or more controller gates (pressure band clamp, spray inhibit interaction, level-program inhibit, ramp limiter, or another control constraint).
Impact: heatup progression realism and pressurizer control behavior after operating pressure entry may diverge from intended baseline response.

evidence.notes: Primary baseline reference to compare intended startup/hold pressurizer behavior against observed heater authority behavior.
Pressurizer pressure-control policy reference for documented limiter behavior and authority expectations.
Startup pressurization behavioral intent reference for hold-band transitions and actuator use.
Investigation completion disposition for DP-0012; transition recommendation READY_FOR_FIX.
